```python
import os
import requests
import json


def handler(pd: "pidedream"):
    try:

        token = os.environ['GITHUB_TOKEN']
        user = "github_username"
        repo = "github_repo"
        event_type = "deploy"
        headers = {
            "User-Agent": "@elog/serverless-api",
            "Accept": '*/*',
            "Authorization": f"token {token}",
        }
        response = requests.post(
            f"https://api.github.com/repos/{user}/{repo}/dispatches",
            headers=headers,
            data=json.dumps({"event_type": event_type})
        )
        # response.raise_for_status()
        print(response.text, response.json())
        return {"message": response.json() or 'Success!'}
    except Exception as e:
        print(e)
```

![](https://image.kuangyichen.com/image/innodb-architecture-8-0.png)


> ğŸ’¡Â **What is log buffer?**


	The log buffer is the memory area that holds data to be written to the log files on disk. Log buffer size is defined by theÂ [`innodb_log_buffer_size`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_log_buffer_size)Â variable. The default size is 16MB. The contents of the log buffer are periodically flushed to disk. A large log buffer enables large transactions to run without the need to write redo log data to disk before the transactions commit. Thus, if you have transactions that update, insert, or delete many rows, increasing the size of the log buffer saves disk I/O.


	TheÂ [`innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit)Â variable controls how the contents of the log buffer are written and flushed to disk. TheÂ [`innodb_flush_log_at_timeout`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_flush_log_at_timeout)Â variable controls log flushing frequency.

> An undo log is a collection of undo log records associated with a single read-write transaction. An undo log record contains information about how to undo the latest change by a transaction to aÂ [clustered index](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_clustered_index)Â record. If another transaction needs to see the original data as part of a consistent read operation, the unmodified data is retrieved from undo log records. Undo logs exist withinÂ [undo log segments](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_undo_log_segment), which are contained withinÂ [rollback segments](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_rollback_segment). Rollback segments reside in theÂ [system tablespace](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_system_tablespace), inÂ [undo tablespaces](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_undo_tablespace), and in theÂ [temporary tablespace](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_temporary_tablespace).  
> â€”â€”[MySQL :: MySQL 5.7 Reference Manual :: 14.6.7 Undo Logs](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/innodb-undo-logs.html)

	**clustered index**


	TheÂ `InnoDB`Â term for aÂ _**primary key**_Â index.Â `InnoDB`Â table storage is organized based on the values of the primary key columns, to speed up queries and sorts involving the primary key columns. For best performance, choose the primary key columns carefully based on the most performance-critical queries. Because modifying the columns of the clustered index is an expensive operation, choose primary columns that are rarely or never updated.


**æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µï¼ˆundo log segmentï¼‰**


> æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µæ˜¯ä¸€ç»„**æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—**çš„é›†åˆã€‚æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µå­˜åœ¨äº**å›æ»šæ®µ**ä¸­ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªæ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µå¯èƒ½åŒ…å«æ¥è‡ªå¤šä¸ªäº‹åŠ¡çš„æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—ã€‚<u>ä¸€ä¸ªæ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µä¸€æ¬¡åªèƒ½è¢«ä¸€ä¸ªäº‹åŠ¡ä½¿ç”¨</u>ï¼Œ<u>ä½†åœ¨äº‹åŠ¡</u><u>**æäº¤**</u><u>æˆ–</u><u>**å›æ»š**</u><u>åå¯ä»¥è¢«é‡æ–°ä½¿ç”¨</u>ã€‚ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ç§°ä¸ºâ€œæ’¤é”€æ®µâ€ã€‚


	**undo log segment**


	A collection ofÂ _**undo logs**_. Undo log segments exists withinÂ _**rollback segments**_. An undo log segment might contain undo logs from multiple transactions. An undo log segment can only be used by one transaction at a time but can be reused after it is released at transactionÂ _**commit**_Â orÂ _**rollback**_. May also be referred to as anÂ â€œundo segmentâ€.


**å›æ»šæ®µ**

	**undo tablespace**


	An undo tablespace containsÂ _**undo logs**_. Undo logs exist withinÂ _**undo log segments**_, which are contained withinÂ _**rollback segments**_. Rollback segments have traditionally resided in the system tablespace. As of MySQL 5.6, rollback segments can reside in undo tablespaces. # å¤è¿°å±•å¼€


> **Tablespace**


	A data file that can hold data for one or moreÂ `InnoDB`Â _**tables**_Â and associatedÂ _**indexes**_.


	TheÂ _**system tablespace**_Â contains theÂ `InnoDB`Â _**data dictionary**_, and prior to MySQL 5.6 holds all otherÂ `InnoDB`Â tables by default.


	TheÂ [`innodb_file_per_table`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_file_per_table)Â option, enabled by default in MySQL 5.6 and higher, allows tables to be created in their own tablespaces. File-per-table tablespaces support features such as efficient storage ofÂ _**off-page columns**_, table compression, and transportable tablespaces. SeeÂ [SectionÂ 14.6.3.2, â€œFile-Per-Table Tablespacesâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/innodb-file-per-table-tablespaces.html)Â for details.


	`InnoDB`Â introduced general tablespaces in MySQL 5.7.6. General tablespaces are shared tablespaces created usingÂ [`CREATE TABLESPACE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/create-tablespace.html)Â syntax. They can be created outside of the MySQL data directory, are capable of holding multiple tables, and support tables of all row formats.


	â€”â€”[MySQL :: MySQL 5.7 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_tablespace)

> **Shared Locks**

> **Exclusive Lock**  
> A kind ofÂ _**lock**_Â that prevents any otherÂ _**transaction**_Â from locking the same row. Depending on the transactionÂ _**isolation level**_, this kind of lock might block other transactions from writing to the same row, or might also block other transactions from reading the same row. > **Record Locks**


	A record lock is a lock on an index record. For example,Â `SELECT c1 FROM t WHERE c1 = 10 FOR UPDATE;`Â prevents any other transaction from inserting, updating, or deleting rows where the value ofÂ `t.c1`Â isÂ `10`.


	Record locks always lock index records, even if a table is defined with no indexes. For such cases,Â `InnoDB`Â creates a hidden clustered index and uses this index for record locking.

> **DML(**Data manipulation language**)**


	Data manipulation language, a set ofÂ _**SQL**_Â statements for performingÂ [`INSERT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/insert.html),Â [`UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/update.html), andÂ [`DELETE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/delete.html)Â operations. TheÂ [`SELECT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)Â statement is sometimes considered as a DML statement, because theÂ `SELECT ... FOR UPDATE`Â form is subject to the same considerations forÂ _**locking**_Â asÂ [`INSERT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/insert.html),Â [`UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/update.html), andÂ [`DELETE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/delete.html).


	DML statements for anÂ `InnoDB`Â table operate in the context of aÂ _**transaction**_, so their effects can beÂ _**committed**_Â orÂ _**rolled back**_Â as a single unit.


> **DDL(**Data definition language**)**


	Data definition language, a set ofÂ _**SQL**_Â statements for manipulating the database itself rather than individual table rows. Includes all forms of theÂ `CREATE`,Â `ALTER`, andÂ `DROP`Â statements. Also includes theÂ `TRUNCATE`Â statement, because it works differently than aÂ `DELETE FROM`Â _**`table_name`**_Â statement, even though the ultimate effect is similar.


	DDL statements automaticallyÂ _**commit**_Â the currentÂ _**transaction**_; they cannot beÂ _**rolled back**_.


> **DCL(**Data control language**)**  
> Data control language, a set ofÂ _**SQL**_Â statements for managing privileges. In MySQL, consists of theÂ [`GRANT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/grant.html)Â andÂ [`REVOKE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/revoke.html)Â statements. Contrast withÂ _**DDL**_Â andÂ _**DML**_.

C**onsistent Read ä¸€è‡´æ€§è¯»**


> **consistent read**


	A read operation that usesÂ _**snapshot**_Â information to present query results based on a point in time, regardless of changes performed by other transactions running at the same time. If queried data has been changed by another transaction, the original data is reconstructed based on the contents of theÂ _**undo log**_. This technique avoids some of theÂ _**locking**_Â issues that can reduceÂ _**concurrency**_Â by forcing transactions to wait for other transactions to finish.
	WithÂ _**REPEATABLE READ**_Â _**isolation level**_, the snapshot is based on the time when the first read operation is performed. WithÂ _**READ COMMITTED**_Â isolation level, the snapshot is reset to the time of each consistent read operation.
	Consistent read is the default mode in whichÂ `InnoDB`Â processesÂ `SELECT`Â statements inÂ _**READ COMMITTED**_Â andÂ _**REPEATABLE READ**_Â isolation levels. Because a consistent read does not set any locks on the tables it accesses, other sessions are free to modify those tables while a consistent read is being performed on the table.

# ç†è§£ä½“ä¼š


æ­»é”æ˜¯æŒ‡å¤šä¸ªäº‹åŠ¡å› ä¸ºäº’ç›¸æŒæœ‰å¯¹æ–¹éœ€è¦çš„é”è€Œæ— æ³•è¿›è¡Œçš„æƒ…å†µã€‚ä¸ºäº†é¿å…æ­»é”ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨äº‹åŠ¡ï¼Œä¿æŒäº‹åŠ¡å°è€ŒçŸ­ï¼Œä»¥åŠåœ¨æ›´æ–°å¤šä¸ªè¡¨æˆ–å¤§èŒƒå›´è¡Œçš„ä¸åŒäº‹åŠ¡ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„æ“ä½œé¡ºåºã€‚å½“æ­»é”å‘ç”Ÿæ—¶ï¼ŒInnoDBä¼šæ£€æµ‹å¹¶å›æ»šå…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªäº‹åŠ¡ã€‚å³ä½¿åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºé€»è¾‘æ­£ç¡®ï¼Œä¹Ÿéœ€è¦å¤„ç†äº‹åŠ¡é‡è¯•çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUSæŸ¥çœ‹æœ€åä¸€ä¸ªæ­»é”ï¼Œå¦‚æœé¢‘ç¹çš„æ­»é”ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å¯ç”¨`innodb_print_all_deadlocks`å°†æ‰€æœ‰æ­»é”çš„ä¿¡æ¯æ‰“å°åˆ°é”™è¯¯æ—¥å¿—ã€‚


> [[MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: 15.7.5 Deadlocks in InnoDB](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlocks.html)]


	A deadlock is a situation where different transactions are unable to proceed because each holds a lock that the other needs. Because both transactions are waiting for a resource to become available, neither ever release the locks it holds.


	A deadlock can occur when transactions lock rows in multiple tables (through statements such asÂ [`UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/update.html)Â orÂ [`SELECT ... FOR UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)), but in the opposite order. A deadlock can also occur when such statements lock ranges of index records and gaps, with each transaction acquiring some locks but not others due to a timing issue. For a deadlock example, seeÂ [SectionÂ 15.7.5.1, â€œAn InnoDB Deadlock Exampleâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlock-example.html).


	To reduce the possibility of deadlocks, use transactions rather thanÂ [`LOCK TABLES`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/lock-tables.html)Â statements; keep transactions that insert or update data small enough that they do not stay open for long periods of time; when different transactions update multiple tables or large ranges of rows, use the same order of operations (such asÂ [`SELECT ... FOR UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)) in each transaction; create indexes on the columns used inÂ [`SELECT ... FOR UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)Â andÂ [`UPDATE ... WHERE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/update.html)Â statements. The possibility of deadlocks is not affected by the isolation level, because the isolation level changes the behavior of read operations, while deadlocks occur because of write operations. For more information about avoiding and recovering from deadlock conditions, seeÂ [SectionÂ 15.7.5.3, â€œHow to Minimize and Handle Deadlocksâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlocks-handling.html).


	When deadlock detection is enabled (the default) and a deadlock does occur,Â `InnoDB`Â detects the condition and rolls back one of the transactions (the victim). If deadlock detection is disabled using theÂ [`innodb_deadlock_detect`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_deadlock_detect)Â variable,Â `InnoDB`Â relies on theÂ [`innodb_lock_wait_timeout`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_lock_wait_timeout)Â setting to roll back transactions in case of a deadlock. Thus, even if your application logic is correct, you must still handle the case where a transaction must be retried. To view the last deadlock in anÂ `InnoDB`Â user transaction, useÂ [`SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/show-engine.html). If frequent deadlocks highlight a problem with transaction structure or application error handling, enableÂ [`innodb_print_all_deadlocks`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_print_all_deadlocks)Â to print information about all deadlocks to theÂ [**mysqld**](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/mysqld.html)Â error log. # å¤è¿°å±•å¼€


> **Deadlock Detection**


	WhenÂ [deadlock detection](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_deadlock_detection)Â is enabled (the default),Â `InnoDB`Â automatically detects transactionÂ [deadlocks](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_deadlock)Â and rolls back a transaction or transactions to break the deadlock.Â `InnoDB`Â tries to pick small transactions to roll back, where the size of a transaction is determined by the number of rows inserted, updated, or deleted.


	`InnoDB`Â is aware of table locks ifÂ `innodb_table_locks = 1`Â (the default) andÂ [`autocommit = 0`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/server-system-variables.html#sysvar_autocommit), and the MySQL layer above it knows about row-level locks. Otherwise,Â `InnoDB`Â cannot detect deadlocks where a table lock set by a MySQLÂ [`LOCK TABLES`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/lock-tables.html)Â statement or a lock set by a storage engine other thanÂ `InnoDB`Â is involved. Resolve these situations by setting the value of theÂ [`innodb_lock_wait_timeout`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_lock_wait_timeout)Â system variable.


	If theÂ `LATEST DETECTED DEADLOCK`Â section ofÂ `InnoDB`Â Monitor output includes a message statingÂ TOO DEEP OR LONG SEARCH IN THE LOCK TABLE WAITS-FOR GRAPH, WE WILL ROLL BACK FOLLOWING TRANSACTION, this indicates that the number of transactions on the wait-for list has reached a limit of 200. A wait-for list that exceeds 200 transactions is treated as a deadlock and the transaction attempting to check the wait-for list is rolled back. The same error may also occur if the locking thread must look at more than 1,000,000 locks owned by transactions on the wait-for list.


	For techniques to organize database operations to avoid deadlocks, seeÂ [SectionÂ 15.7.5, â€œDeadlocks in InnoDBâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlocks.html).


	**Disabling Deadlock Detection**


	On high concurrency systems, deadlock detection can cause a slowdown when numerous threads wait for the same lock. At times, it may be more efficient to disable deadlock detection and rely on theÂ [`innodb_lock_wait_timeout`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_lock_wait_timeout)Â setting for transaction rollback when a deadlock occurs. Deadlock detection can be disabled using theÂ [`innodb_deadlock_detect`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_deadlock_detect)Â variable.


	â€”â€”ã€Š[MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: 15.7.5.2 Deadlock Detection](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlock-detection.html)ã€‹

# å¤è¿°å±•å¼€


> **How to Minimize and Handle Deadlocks**


	This section builds on the conceptual information about deadlocks inÂ [SectionÂ 15.7.5.2, â€œDeadlock Detectionâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlock-detection.html). It explains how to organize database operations to minimize deadlocks and the subsequent error handling required in applications.


	[Deadlocks](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_deadlock)Â are a classic problem in transactional databases, but they are not dangerous unless they are so frequent that you cannot run certain transactions at all. Normally, you must write your applications so that they are always prepared to re-issue a transaction if it gets rolled back because of a deadlock.


	`InnoDB`Â uses automatic row-level locking. You can get deadlocks even in the case of transactions that just insert or delete a single row. That is because these operations are not reallyÂ â€œatomicâ€; they automatically set locks on the (possibly several) index records of the row inserted or deleted.


	You can cope with deadlocks and reduce the likelihood of their occurrence with the following techniques:

	- At any time, issueÂ [`SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/show-engine.html)Â to determine the cause of the most recent deadlock. That can help you to tune your application to avoid deadlocks.
	- If frequent deadlock warnings cause concern, collect more extensive debugging information by enabling theÂ [`innodb_print_all_deadlocks`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_print_all_deadlocks)Â variable. Information about each deadlock, not just the latest one, is recorded in the MySQLÂ [error log](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_error_log). Disable this option when you are finished debugging.
	- Always be prepared to re-issue a transaction if it fails due to deadlock. Deadlocks are not dangerous. Just try again.
	- Keep transactions small and short in duration to make them less prone to collision.
	- Commit transactions immediately after making a set of related changes to make them less prone to collision. In particular, do not leave an interactiveÂ [**mysql**](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/mysql.html)Â session open for a long time with an uncommitted transaction.
	- If you useÂ [locking reads](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_locking_read)Â ([`SELECT ... FOR UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)Â orÂ [`SELECT ... FOR SHARE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)), try using a lower isolation level such asÂ [`READ COMMITTED`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-transaction-isolation-levels.html#isolevel_read-committed).
	- When modifying multiple tables within a transaction, or different sets of rows in the same table, do those operations in a consistent order each time. Then transactions form well-defined queues and do not deadlock. For example, organize database operations into functions within your application, or call stored routines, rather than coding multiple similar sequences ofÂ `INSERT`,Â `UPDATE`, andÂ `DELETE`Â statements in different places.
	- Add well-chosen indexes to your tables so that your queries scan fewer index records and set fewer locks. UseÂ [`EXPLAIN SELECT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/explain.html)Â to determine which indexes the MySQL server regards as the most appropriate for your queries.
	- Use less locking. If you can afford to permit aÂ [`SELECT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)Â to return data from an old snapshot, do not add aÂ `FOR UPDATE`Â orÂ `FOR SHARE`Â clause to it. Using theÂ [`READ COMMITTED`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-transaction-isolation-levels.html#isolevel_read-committed)Â isolation level is good here, because each consistent read within the same transaction reads from its own fresh snapshot.
	- If nothing else helps, serialize your transactions with table-level locks. The correct way to useÂ [`LOCK TABLES`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/lock-tables.html)Â with transactional tables, such asÂ `InnoDB`Â tables, is to begin a transaction withÂ `SET autocommit = 0`Â (notÂ [`START TRANSACTION`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/commit.html)) followed byÂ [`LOCK TABLES`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/lock-tables.html), and to not callÂ [`UNLOCK TABLES`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/lock-tables.html)Â until you commit the transaction explicitly. For example, if you need to write to tableÂ `t1`Â and read from tableÂ `t2`, you can do this:

		`SET autocommit=0;
		LOCK TABLES t1 WRITE, t2 READ, ...;`
		_`... do something with tables t1 and t2 here ...`_`COMMIT;
		UNLOCK TABLES;`


		Table-level locks prevent concurrent updates to the table, avoiding deadlocks at the expense of less responsiveness for a busy system.

	- Another way to serialize transactions is to create an auxiliaryÂ â€œsemaphoreâ€Â table that contains just a single row. Have each transaction update that row before accessing other tables. In that way, all transactions happen in a serial fashion. Note that theÂ `InnoDB`Â instant deadlock detection algorithm also works in this case, because the serializing lock is a row-level lock. With MySQL table-level locks, the timeout method must be used to resolve deadlocks.

	â€”â€”ã€Š[MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: 15.7.5.3 How to Minimize and Handle Deadlocks](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-deadlocks-handling.html)ã€‹

## **Transaction Scheduling**


> In the fields ofÂ [databases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database)Â andÂ [transaction processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transaction_processing)Â (transaction management), aÂ **schedule**Â (orÂ **history**) of a system is an abstract model to describeÂ [execution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Execution_(computing))Â of transactions running in the system. Often it is aÂ _list_Â of operations (actions) ordered by time, performed by a set ofÂ [transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_transaction)Â that are executed together in the system. If the order in time between certain operations is not determined by the system, then aÂ [_partial order_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_order)Â is used. Examples of such operations are requesting a read operation, reading, writing, aborting,Â [committing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commit_(data_management)), requesting aÂ [lock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lock_(computer_science)), locking, etc. Not all transaction operation types should be included in a schedule, and typically only selected operation types (e.g., data access operations) are included, as needed to reason about and describe certain phenomena. Schedules and schedule properties are fundamental concepts in databaseÂ [concurrency control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concurrency_control)Â theory.

> What is Page ([MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_page))


	A unit representing how much dataÂ `InnoDB`Â transfers at any one time between disk (theÂ _**data files**_) and memory (theÂ _**buffer pool**_). A page can contain one or moreÂ _**rows**_, depending on how much data is in each row. If a row does not fit entirely into a single page,Â `InnoDB`Â sets up additional pointer-style data structures so that the information about the row can be stored in one page.


	One way to fit more data in each page is to useÂ _**compressed row format**_. For tables that use BLOBs or large text fields,Â _**compact row format**_Â allows those large columns to be stored separately from the rest of the row, reducing I/O overhead and memory usage for queries that do not reference those columns.


	WhenÂ `InnoDB`Â reads or writes sets of pages as a batch to increase I/O throughput, it reads or writes anÂ _**extent**_Â at a time.


	All theÂ `InnoDB`Â disk data structures within a MySQL instance share the sameÂ _**page size**_.

> What is Extend ([MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_extent))


	A group ofÂ _**pages**_Â within aÂ _**tablespace**_. For the defaultÂ _**page size**_Â of 16KB, an extent contains 64 pages. In MySQL 5.6, the page size for anÂ `InnoDB`Â instance can be 4KB, 8KB, or 16KB, controlled by theÂ [`innodb_page_size`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_page_size)Â configuration option. For 4KB, 8KB, and 16KB pages sizes, the extent size is always 1MB (or 1048576 bytes).


	Support for 32KB and 64KBÂ `InnoDB`Â page sizes was added in MySQL 5.7.6. For a 32KB page size, the extent size is 2MB. For a 64KB page size, the extent size is 4MB.


	`InnoDB`Â features such asÂ _**segments**_,Â _**read-ahead**_Â requests and theÂ _**doublewrite buffer**_Â use I/O operations that read, write, allocate, or free data one extent at a time.

éšç€æ•°æ®çš„æ’å…¥å’Œåˆ é™¤ï¼Œsegmentä¼šå¢é•¿å’Œç¼©å°ã€‚ å½“ä¸€ä¸ªsegmentéœ€è¦æ›´å¤šç©ºé—´æ—¶ï¼Œå®ƒä¸€æ¬¡æ‰©å±•ä¸€ä¸ª extendï¼ˆ1MBï¼‰ã€‚ ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œå½“ä¸å†éœ€è¦æŸä¸ªèŒƒå›´å†…çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®æ—¶ï¼Œæ®µä¼šé‡Šæ”¾è¯¥ extend çš„ç©ºé—´ã€‚


> What is Segment ï¼ˆ[MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_segment)ï¼‰


	A division within anÂ `InnoDB`Â _**tablespace**_. If a tablespace is analogous to a directory, the segments are analogous to files within that directory. A segment can grow. New segments can be created.


	For example, within aÂ _**file-per-table**_Â tablespace, table data is in one segment and each associated index is in its own segment. TheÂ _**system tablespace**_Â contains many different segments, because it can hold many tables and their associated indexes. Prior to MySQL 8.0, the system tablespace also includes one or moreÂ _**rollback segments**_Â used forÂ _**undo logs**_.


	Segments grow and shrink as data is inserted and deleted. When a segment needs more room, it is extended by oneÂ _**extent**_Â (1 megabyte) at a time. Similarly, a segment releases one extent's worth of space when all the data in that extent is no longer needed.

	> [MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_flush)


		To write changes to the database files, that had been buffered in a memory area or a temporary disk storage area. TheÂ `InnoDB`Â storage structures that are periodically flushed include theÂ _**redo log**_, theÂ _**undo log**_, and theÂ _**buffer pool**_.

crash recovery


> [MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_crash_recovery)  
> The cleanup activities that occur when MySQL is started again after aÂ _**crash**_. ForÂ _**InnoDB**_Â tables, changes from incomplete transactions are replayed using data from theÂ _**redo log**_. Changes that wereÂ _**committed**_Â before the crash, but not yet written into theÂ _**data files**_, are reconstructed from theÂ _**doublewrite buffer**_. When the database is shut down normally, this type of activity is performed during shutdown by theÂ _**purge**_Â operation.  
> During normal operation, committed data can be stored in theÂ _**change buffer**_Â for a period of time before being written to the data files. There is always a tradeoff between keeping the data files up-to-date, which introduces performance overhead during normal operation, and buffering the data, which can make shutdown and crash recovery take longer.


fuzzy checkpointing


> [MySQL :: MySQL 8.0 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/glossary.html#glos_fuzzy_checkpointing)  
> A technique thatÂ _**flushes**_Â small batches ofÂ _**dirty pages**_Â from theÂ _**buffer pool**_, rather than flushing all dirty pages at once which would disrupt database processing.

## What is PEST Analysis


åœ¨å•†ä¸šåˆ†æä¸­ï¼ŒPEST åˆ†æï¼ˆâ€œæ”¿æ²»ã€ç»æµã€ç¤¾ä¼šæ–‡åŒ–å’ŒæŠ€æœ¯â€ï¼‰æè¿°äº†æˆ˜ç•¥ç®¡ç†çš„ç¯å¢ƒæ‰«æéƒ¨åˆ†ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨çš„å®è§‚ç¯å¢ƒå› ç´ æ¡†æ¶ã€‚ å®ƒæ˜¯è¿›è¡Œæˆ˜ç•¥åˆ†ææˆ–å¸‚åœºç ”ç©¶æ—¶å¤–éƒ¨ç¯å¢ƒåˆ†æçš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œå¹¶æ¦‚è¿°äº†éœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘çš„ä¸åŒå®è§‚ç¯å¢ƒå› ç´ ã€‚ å®ƒæ˜¯äº†è§£å¸‚åœºå¢é•¿æˆ–è¡°é€€ã€ä¸šåŠ¡åœ°ä½ã€æ½œåŠ›å’Œè¿è¥æ–¹å‘çš„æˆ˜ç•¥å·¥å…·ã€‚


> InÂ [business analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_analysis),Â **PEST analysis**Â ("political, economic, socio-cultural and technological") describes a framework of macro-environmental factors used in theÂ [environmental scanning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_scanning)Â component ofÂ [strategic management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_management). It is part of an external environment analysis when conducting a strategic analysis or doingÂ [market research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_research), and gives an overview of the different macro-environmental factors to be taken into consideration. It is a strategic tool for understanding market growth or decline, business position, potential and direction for operations.


	â€”â€”ã€Š[PEST analysis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PEST_analysis)ã€‹


## The first developer


PEST åˆ†æç”± `Aguilar` äº `1967` å¹´å¼€å‘ï¼Œä½œä¸º<u>ç¯å¢ƒæ‰«ææ¡†æ¶</u>ã€‚`Aguilar`è®¤ä¸ºï¼Œä¼ä¸šå¿…é¡»æ‰«æå¯èƒ½å½±å“æˆ˜ç•¥çš„ç»æµã€æŠ€æœ¯ã€æ”¿æ²»å’Œç¤¾ä¼šç±»åˆ«ï¼ˆETPSï¼‰ï¼Œå°†ç¯å¢ƒæ‰«æå®šä¹‰å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼šâ€œæ‰«ææœ‰å…³å…¬å¸å¤–éƒ¨ç¯å¢ƒä¸­çš„äº‹ä»¶å’Œå…³ç³»çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¿™äº›ä¿¡æ¯å°†æœ‰åŠ©äºé«˜å±‚ç®¡ç†äººå‘˜ ç®¡ç†å±‚çš„ä»»åŠ¡æ˜¯åˆ¶å®šå…¬å¸æœªæ¥çš„è¡ŒåŠ¨æ–¹é’ˆã€‚â€


> PEST analysis was developed in 1967 byÂ [Aguilar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_J._Aguilar)Â as anÂ [environmental scanning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_scanning)Â framework.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PEST_analysis#cite_note-:0-1)Â Aguilar argued that firms must scan the economic, technical, political and social categories (ETPS) that may affect strategy, defining environmental scanning as follows, â€œscanning for information about events and relationships in a companyâ€™s outside environment, the knowledge of which would assist top management in its task of charting the companyâ€™s future course of action.â€

## PEST Composition


> The basic PEST analysis includes four factors:

	- _**Political**_Â factors relate to how theÂ [government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government)Â intervenes in the economy. Specifically, political factors have areas includingÂ [tax policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_policy),Â [labour law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_law),Â [environmental law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_law),Â [trade restrictions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_restriction),Â [tariffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariffs), and political stability. Political factors may also include goods and services which the government aims to provide or be provided ([merit goods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merit_good)) and those that the government does not want to be provided ([demerit goods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demerit_good)Â or merit bads). Furthermore, governments have a high impact on theÂ [health](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health),Â [education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education), andÂ [infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrastructure)Â of a nation.
	- _**Economic**_Â factors includeÂ [economic growth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_growth),Â [exchange rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exchange_rate),Â [inflation rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflation_rate), andÂ [interest rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interest_rate). These factors can drastically affect how a business operates. For example, interest rates affect a firm'sÂ [cost of capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_capital)Â and therefore to what extent a business grows and expands.
	- _**Social**_Â factors include the cultural aspects and health consciousness, population growth rate, age distribution, career attitudes and emphasis on safety. High trends in social factors affect the demand for a company's products and how that company operates. For example, the ageing population may imply a smaller and less-willing workforce (thus increasing the cost of labour). Furthermore, companies may change various management strategies to adapt to social trends caused from this (such as recruiting older workers).
	- _**Technological**_Â factors include technological aspects likeÂ [R&D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%26D)Â activity,Â [automation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automation), technology incentives and the rate ofÂ [technological change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_change). These can determineÂ [barriers to entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_to_entry), minimum efficient production level and influence theÂ [outsourcing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outsourcing)Â decisions. Furthermore, technological shifts would affect costs, quality, and lead toÂ [innovation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation)

## SWOT åˆ†æï¼ˆStrengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threatsï¼‰


SWOT åˆ†æï¼ˆæˆ– SWOT çŸ©é˜µï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€ç§**æˆ˜ç•¥è§„åˆ’**å’Œ**æˆ˜ç•¥ç®¡ç†æŠ€æœ¯**ï¼Œç”¨äºå¸®åŠ©**ä¸ªäºº**æˆ–**ç»„ç»‡**è¯†åˆ«ä¸ä¸šåŠ¡ç«äº‰æˆ–é¡¹ç›®è§„åˆ’ç›¸å…³çš„ä¼˜**åŠ¿ã€åŠ£åŠ¿ã€æœºä¼šå’Œå¨èƒ**ã€‚ æœ‰æ—¶ç§°ä¸ºæƒ…å¢ƒè¯„ä¼°æˆ–æƒ…å¢ƒåˆ†æã€‚


> [SWOT analysis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis)


	**SWOT analysis**Â (orÂ **SWOT matrix**) is aÂ [strategic planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_planning)Â andÂ [strategic management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_management)Â technique used to help a person or organization identify Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats related toÂ [business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business)Â competition orÂ [project planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_planning). It is sometimes calledÂ [situational assessment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_management)Â or situational analysis.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis#cite_note-1)Â Additional acronyms using the same components include TOWS and WOTS-UP.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis#cite_note-Weihrich1982-2)[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis#cite_note-3)


	This technique is designed for use in the preliminary stages of decision-making processes and can be used as a tool for evaluation of the strategic position of organizations of many kinds (for-profit enterprises, local and national governments, NGOs, etc.).[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis#cite_note-4)Â It is intended to identify the internal and external factors that are favorable and unfavorable to achieving the objectives of the venture or project. Users of a SWOT analysis often ask and answer questions to generate meaningful information for each category to make the tool useful and identify theirÂ [competitive advantage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_advantage). SWOT has been described as a tried-and-true tool of strategic analysis,[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis#cite_note-5)Â but has also been criticized for its limitations, and alternatives have been developed.

## SWOTç»„æˆ


SWOT(Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats)

- Strengths ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼šä¸šåŠ¡æˆ–é¡¹ç›®æ¯”å…¶ä»–ä¸šåŠ¡æˆ–é¡¹ç›®å…·æœ‰ä¼˜åŠ¿çš„ç‰¹å¾
- Weaknesses åŠ£åŠ¿ï¼šä½¿ä¼ä¸šæˆ–é¡¹ç›®ç›¸å¯¹äºå…¶ä»–ä¼ä¸šæˆ–é¡¹ç›®å¤„äºåŠ£åŠ¿çš„ç‰¹å¾
- Opportunities æœºä¼šï¼šç¯å¢ƒä¸­ä¼ä¸šæˆ–é¡¹ç›®å¯ä»¥åˆ©ç”¨çš„å…ƒç´ æ¥å‘æŒ¥å…¶ä¼˜åŠ¿
- Threats å¨èƒï¼šç¯å¢ƒä¸­å¯èƒ½ç»™ä¸šåŠ¡æˆ–é¡¹ç›®å¸¦æ¥éº»çƒ¦çš„å…ƒç´ 

> [SWOT analysis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis)


	The name is an acronym for the four components the technique examines:

	- _Strengths_: characteristics of the business or project that give it an advantage over others
	- _Weaknesses_: characteristics that place the business or project at a disadvantage relative to others
	- _Opportunities_: elements in the environment that the business or project could exploit to its advantage
	- _Threats_: elements in the environment that could cause trouble for the business or project

	Results of the assessment are often presented in the form of aÂ [matrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Table_(information)),[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SWOT_analysis#cite_note-Ansoff1980-6)Â or simply as paragraphs.

åœ¨MySQL 5.0ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªç±»ä¼¼çš„åŠŸèƒ½å¯ç”¨ï¼Œç§°ä¸ºæ›´æ–°æ—¥å¿—ã€‚åœ¨MySQL 5.0åŠæ›´é«˜ç‰ˆæœ¬ä¸­ï¼ŒäºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ—¥å¿—å–ä»£äº†æ›´æ–°æ—¥å¿—ã€‚


> **binary log(bin log)**


	A file containing a record of all statements or row changes that attempt to change table data. The contents of the binary log can be replayed to bring replicas up to date in aÂ _**replication**_Â scenario, or to bring a database up to date after restoring table data from a backup. The binary logging feature can be turned on and off, although Oracle recommends always enabling it if you use replication or perform backups.
	You can examine the contents of the binary log, or replay it during replication or recovery, by using theÂ [**mysqlbinlog**](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/mysqlbinlog.html)Â command. For full information about the binary log, seeÂ [SectionÂ 5.4.4, â€œThe Binary Logâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/binary-log.html). For MySQL configuration options related to the binary log, seeÂ [SectionÂ 17.1.6.4, â€œBinary Logging Options and Variablesâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/replication-options-binary-log.html).
	For theÂ _**MySQL Enterprise Backup**_Â product, the file name of the binary log and the current position within the file are important details. To record this information for the source when taking a backup in a replication context, you can specify theÂ `--slave-info`Â option.
	Prior to MySQL 5.0, a similar capability was available, known as the update log. In MySQL 5.0 and higher, the binary log replaces the update log.

> **NoSQL**Â (originally referring to "non-[SQL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL)" or "non-relational")[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NoSQL#cite_note-1)Â is an approach toÂ [database](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database)Â design that focuses on providing a mechanism forÂ [storage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_data_storage)Â andÂ [retrieval](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_retrieval)Â of data that is modeled in means other than the tabular relations used inÂ [relational databases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_database). Instead of the typical tabular structure of a relational database, NoSQL databases house data within one data structure. Since this non-relational database design does not require aâ€¯schema, it offers rapidâ€¯scalabilityâ€¯to manageâ€¯large and typically unstructured data sets.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NoSQL#cite_note-2)Â NoSQL systems are also sometimes calledÂ _"Not only SQL"_Â to emphasize that they may supportÂ [SQL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL)-like query languages or sit alongside SQL databases inÂ [polyglot-persistent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyglot_persistence)Â architectures.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NoSQL#cite_note-3)[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NoSQL#cite_note-4)
